dialogues.text: —_—— REN OWN ~ DAY A big, almost empty schoolroom in a small American town in a timeless age between the late 1920's and the early 1930's. The SILENCE is underlined by the breathy TICK of a schoolroom clock and the SCRATCHING of two pens. We SEE TWO YOUNG BOYS sitting at their desks writing. Their names are WILL HALLOWAY and JIM NIGHTSHADE. will is as fair as Jim is dark. The only other person in the room is MISS FOLEY, the schoolmistress. She is about forty, very plain indeed, with a dress buttoning up to her neck and an expression of sadness. On the blackboard behind her, in copperplate handwriting, is the line that the boys have to write out as a punish=- ment: "We must not whisper to each other in class."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE Will, his paper covered with the lines, writing out the last of them. Then we SEE Jim. He is drawing on an odd sheet of paper, a cruel caricature of Miss Foley, her beaky nose, her jutting chin. As Jim finishes drawing, he HEARS a step behind him and, opening the lid of his desk a erack, slid the drawing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: MISS FOLEY
dialogues.text: Finished?

dialogues.speaker: JIM AND WILL
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Foley.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FOLEY
dialogues.text: Then you may leave. Quietly. And let this be a lesson to the both of you. I will not have whispering.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (getting up) Thank you, Miss Foley. They CLATTER out of the room, gathering speed as they reach the door.

dialogues.speaker: JIM

CAMERA PULLS UP AND BACK to reveal: TOM FURY staring in at: THE OBLONG OF ICE in the shop window, with the shape of beauty in it. Faint MUSIC stirs. The red bloodstone ring seems to pulse with life.

dialogues.speaker: TOM FURY
dialogues.text: He stands hearing VOICES from other days, a GIRL LAUGHING calling, “Goodbye, goodbye!" His face is haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We almost SEE a beautiful face within the ice, eyes close in sleep. ANOTHER ANGLE . Pury quickens for: the shop door opens, slowly, all by it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Fury, inside, looks down, quickens, because:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ghost of an eyelid within the ice stirs. Fury puts out his hand to the ice. It begins to melt, dripping to the floor. He stares. The ice melts, fast! The front door shuts, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church clock STRIKES midnight. As it does so, *e we SEE the empty Main Street. mo,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We catch a glimpse of the Wooden Indian inside the cigar store... of the barber's pole, illumined, turning, lighting the empty street... And the stone lion on the outside of the library - beyond which:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING THROUGH WINDOW we SEE CHARLES HALLOWAY, stacking books on shelves. He turns his head suddenly towards the window as though reacting to some o.s. sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SS ee LDE = NIGHT We SEE in LONG SHOT the rooftops of the town and, beyond them, the trees and dark sky. And HEAR the CHUFF of an approaching train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will pops his eyes open, in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sr OSE SIM'S BEDROOM — NIGHT Jim does the same. The o.s. train SOUND is nearer.

dialogues.speaker: SRS LON AY AND NIGHTSHADE HOUSES
dialogues.text: At their windows, the boys lean out simultaneously, give each other a stare, then look off at:

dialogues.speaker: THE HORIZON
dialogues.text: A small storm cloud of steam rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys, at their windows, stare.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: appears, tossing up sparks. There is a faint rumble of THUNDER, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: = i IGE SHADE HOUSES ~ NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS AT THEIR WINDOWS
dialogues.text: Jim hisses, a gleeful whisper.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (whispering) The carnival! The carnival's come!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (whispering) At three in the morning? No!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (whispering) Hell, yes! C'mon. Jim pulls in. We SEE him through the window as he jigs around, pulling on clothes. Will sees this, does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim scampers down the side of his house. Will, at his window, half-dressed, whispers down.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: {a whisper) Jim, wait! Jim looks up, grins and runs. ‘Will slides down the side of his house, using hidden run He lands, runs, still hoisting his pants, lacing shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SRS VERSA ERTS OF GREEN TOWN
dialogues.text: The hoys race together, leaping bushes, Clipping hedges - finally reaching meadow-country, with the train SOUND drawing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys reach the shadow of an embankment. The train THUNDERS above... The windows are empty... The boys’ heads and eyes follow, looking up, as:

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: passes, carved circus car after car, cage after cage, with shadows pacing in them, beasts carved and glaring from every cornice.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: run. O©.s. the train WHISTLE SCREAMS with a billion human voices in misery. Will stops, hands to his ears. Jim, riven, stops with him, amidst that WAILING torment.  Prod. 40a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the SOUND, as of a thousand dead souls, stone angels weep dust from their eyes and mouths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will unplugs his ears. Jim relaxes. Both leap and run aga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys run INTO SHOT - stop short, in open-mouthed dis- belief as they see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The railroad track comes to an abrupt end in a writhing, tortured jumble of rusty iron, embedded in a tangle of grass and weeds.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BOYS
dialogues.text: They stare at each other in open-mouthed amazement. Turn to look at the track again - and see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, a puff of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BOYS
dialogues.text: They start to run towards the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys reach the crest of the rise and pause, looking down at:

dialogues.speaker: THE MEADOW
dialogues.text: A carnival is laid out there, complete, dark, entire, who its reptilian skin breathing, sighing... From one of the tents mirrors swarm and flash.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: Jim stands a long moment, transfixed, staring, the flicke flash of the mirrors in his eyes. Then he turns to Will: Jim (triumphant) See? It was true! I told you!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: But... He stops, shivers suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Come on! He starts down the hill toward the carnival. Will hesitat a moment, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys enter the midway, dark, deserted, silent. They SEE the flashes of light as the Mirror Maze reflects distant lightning. And HEAR a strange soughing breath- ing SOUND from the tent canvases billowing around them in the darkness as though sucking in the night air.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: move down the midway, glancing from side to side nervousl They jump as they HEAR a sudden CREAKING NOISE 0.8. - tur to SEE: The door of one of the caravans is ajar. It moves on its hinges, rustily. Will and Jim look at each other, then approach and hesitantly enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite empty. Dust and cobwebs everywhere. Will shivers again. There is a sudden RUSTLE from one corner, and a large, hairy spider, looking almost like a human hand, scuttles across the floor. The boys simultaneously turn and run out, almost in panic

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MIDWAY
dialogues.text: The boys come hurtling out of the caravan. At the same moment, we HEAR the CALLIOPE start up. They pause, look towards it and SEE:

dialogues.speaker: THE CALLIOPE
dialogues.text: It seems to be playing its jangling TUNE all by itself. There is no one there.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: run hot-foot down the midway out of the carnival. The CALLIOPE MUSIC continues o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES HALLOWAY, coming out of the door, hears faint CALLIOPE MUSIC o.s., turns, peers, shakes his head, locks the door.  Prod. 0233 - 8/24/81 25. 47 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faint CALLIOPE MUSIC continues o.s. as Halloway, walking along the night street, stops, looks in at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The undertaker's window, dimly lit. The empty sawhorses. No coffin. No ice block.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: His eyes, startled, glance down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The melted ice on the floor. And then he SEES the red blo stone ring lying in a pool of water on the floor, and a few strands of long, lovely hair.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOWAY
dialogues.text: eyes wondering, in the dark. CALLIOPE MUSIC con- tinues over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halloway lets himself in, closes the front door softly behind him. Starts up the stairs in the dim light from the street lamp outside. Pauses, startled, as he looks up and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the small figure of his son, clad in pajamas, sitting at the top of the stairs. Halloway mounts the remaining steps, pauses beside him:

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: What is it, son? Can't sleep? Will shakes his head “no”.

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thought I heard a train. Couldn't have been. Not at this time of night.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, it couldn't've been. {he looks at his father) Couldn't be a carnival, could there? Not in October. I mean, you never saw no little scraps of paper, did you? Not about any carnival coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halloway doesn't answer. We HEAR the clock strike three.

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: Three o'clock. They call it the soul's midnight.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Do they? Why?

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess it's a time when a lot of folks die. Will looks frightened for a moment; Halloway tries to reassure him.

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Only 01d people. I only meant old people.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (repeats slowly) Old people...

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: Will, we should have a talk some- time. Just you and I...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (nervously) What about?

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: Oh, about when you were small. That time we took a picnic down by Indigo River. Look, son, I know you got a fright and... Will stands up suddenly. He appears nervous as he moves away upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WILL .
dialogues.text: Better get back to bed now. Mom wouldn't like us to be up this late. Talking. She'd say we got to think of tomorrow. He moves up the last step into the darkness. Mr. Halloway watches him disappear.

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: Guess you're right, son. Trouble is... this time of night, tomorrow seems a long way off... We HEAR a faint RUMBLE OF THUNDER in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. HORIZON ABOVE GREEN TOWN — MORNING 49 The sun rises. The sky is blue, blue. The sun is yellow, my God, yellow! :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys' windows fly open. They glance out at each other, then at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meadow where’ the carnival still lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Halloway is standing among the fallen leaves in the garden with a rake in her hand. She looks up and calls:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING UP at Will's window. Will looks down and calls to his mother:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Coming, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTSHADE HOUSE
dialogues.text: SHOOTING UP at Mrs. Nightshade's window. Mrs. Night- shade, in a frilly and rather grubby negligee, her cat in her arms, is leaning out of the window. We HEAR the SOUND of an axe chopping wood as she calls down:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NIGHTSHADE
dialogues.text: Jim! JIM 0.S. Yes, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NIGHTSHADE
dialogues.text: Nice lot of logs for the store, remember! Your Uncle Sydney's coming for supper.

dialogues.speaker: BOTH HOUSES AND BACKYARDS
dialogues.text: We SEE Jim chopping logs in the Nightshade backyard, and Will raking up leaves in b.g. in the Halloway backyard. Jim calls up to his mother:

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Who's my Uncle Sydney? Did I ever get to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NIGHTSHADE
dialogues.text: What did you say, son?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing, I guess. He crashes his axe into a log. Mrs. Nightshade smiles at her window and disappears from view with her cat, Tyba saying:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NIGHTSHADE
dialogues.text: Good boy, Jim. We want a nice cozy fire for our visitor. We HEAR the distant SOUND of the CALLIOPE at the carnival which continues over:

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING WILL
dialogues.text: still raking leaves. We SEE Jim chopping up logs in the b.g. A group of CHILDREN, one RATTLING a stick against the fence, passes by. They pause to watch Will at work.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: You coming to the carnival?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Already seen it.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Know-it-all! The children run on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Halloway puts her head out of the kitchen window and calls to Will:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: You finished those leaves, Will?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (calls back) So long as no more don't fall down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: Run along, then. Only don't you dare be late for supper, do you hear me? She closes the window. Will drops his rake. We SEE Jim drive his axe into a log and leave it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two boys running out of their backyards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a SERIES OF SHOTS we SEE the boys running, sometimes in tandem stride for stride, sometimes racing, sometimes tumbling, sometimes leaping, heading at full stretch towa the meadow and the o.s. SOUNDS of the carnival. EXT. HILL ABOVE MEADOW - pay 54 — OW = DAY Will and Jim reach the top of the hill, blink, then run o down the hill towards:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the Carnival, the boys pause. Will looks round, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Why, gosh darn, it's just a plain ordinary old carnival!

dialogues.speaker: PANNING THE CARNIVAL
dialogues.text: We SEE what they see: an ordinary carnival with ordinary colors of lemon and brass and cotton candy and sideshows, with boring - instead of mysterious - CALLIOPE MUSIC. The first CROWDS are gathering. JIM'S VOICE 0.S. No, it can't be! It can't be ordinary!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BOYS
dialogues.text: Jim strides along the midway, Will following, happily.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: ‘Course it is. Good and ordinary. We just couldn't see last night in the dark! They pause at a 'Test Your Strength' machine. One of the TOWNSMEN has just completed. his try, unsuccessfully; the onlookers JEER.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSMAN
dialogues.text: It's fixed. A huge, redheaded, blue-eyed man (COOGER), in charge of the machine, picks up the hammer as though it were a feather, crashes it down - and the BELL CLANGS. Slight GASPS from the onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing through the small crowd on his crutch, we see Ed, the barman. He picks up the hammer with his one hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (at front of. crowd) Go on, Ed! Ed glances at him, grins.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Hold this. He hands his crutch to Will. Balancing on his one leg, he swings the hammer with his one arm.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And, CLANG, the bell rings. The onlookers APPLAUD and Will and Jim embrace him. Ed's triumphant smile makes up for a lot of his past. Cooger eyes him thoughtfully a moment, then reaches be- hind him, hands him a card.

dialogues.speaker: COOGER
dialogues.text: Your prize, sir - free pass to our fabulous mirror maze. Ed takes it, moves off with the boys. INT. THE ASSYRIAN FORTUNE TELLER'S TENT - DAY whe 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face is hidden by a dark, lacy veil.

dialogues.speaker: FORTUNE TELLER
dialogues.text: I see your place of work, my good sir. And a red and white pole turn- ing... CAMERA PULLS BACK and we SEE Mr. Crosetti facing her, amazed and sweating slightly, his luxuriant hair, beard and moustache shining with pomade. She holds one of his hands between hers, reading his palm. On one of her fingers glows the red bloodstone ving.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CROSETTI
dialogues.text: It's a miracle! Your eyes see everything!

dialogues.speaker: FORTUNE TELLER
dialogues.text: Only I think something is missing from your life. Something that could make you so happy... (a whisper) Ladies! You have lived her a long time without the scent of ladies’ skin... (Mr. Crosetti gasps) They are waiting for you, my good sir. Can you not hear their dresses rustling? Call them. They are long- ing to comfort you and bring you con- tentment. Crosetti's gaze lifts to the Fortune Teller's face. Shadows stir under the veil. Her eyes seem to burn through the lace; her smile reminds us of THE MOST BEAUTIFUL WOMAN IN THE WORLD. ek

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys and Ed move along the midway, looking at the various stalls and sideshows. Then suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hey, look! Wild animals! We see cages in which typical, ordinary fairground beasts prowl. Jim and Will march past, pulling faces at the animals, growling, pointing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (glancing around) Where's Ed? Jim looks around also, and they SEE, some way away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed standing locking into the mirror maze. EXT. MIRROR MAZE ~— DAY 58 The boys run towards him, but before they reach him he hobbles in. They pull to a stop at the entrance and see him standing just inside, his expression rapt, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By some juxtaposition of the mirrors, Ed's reflection is that of a whole, normal man, all his limbs intact. He moves as though to throw a football. Then, grinning,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘hobbles further into the maze of mirrors, the many re- 59 60 61 62 flections fading, disappearing, until he's almost gone from sight.

dialogues.speaker: ED'S VOICE 0.S,
dialogues.text: (diminishing) Throw! Run! Grab! Touchdown! God, oh God, mant

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The boys turn away. As they move off, their attention attracted by a large tent, decorated with pictures of various freaks.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (pointing at a par- ticularly grotesque picture) When did you pose for that, Will Halloway? LAUGHING, he runs off, Will in pursuit. EXT. A TENT - “TEMPLE OF TEMPTATION" - DAY Jim darts in at the tent to fit his eye to a hole in the canvas. Will looks up to read the sign above the tent - "TEMPLE OF TEMPTATION".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eye to the hole, from which comes flesh-colored illumination. We HEAR lascivious MUSIC o.s.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH HOLE
dialogues.text: We SEE a belly dancing show. At first the DANCERS seem like any ordinary fairground sideshow, but then, through Jim's eyes, they appear as erotic fantasies. Their long limbs seem to stretch out towards him across the AUDIENCE. In the audience we can see Mr. Crosetti sweating, watching wide-eyed. EXT, “TEMPLE OF TEMPTATION" - DAY Jim's eyes glint. His cheeks glow. His mouth drops wide. Will, seeing this, suddenly hits him. But Jim ignores him, as the MUSIC from inside the tent grows. . INT, “TEMPLE OF TEMPTATION" - DAY

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S EYE
dialogues.text: seen through the hole in the canvas. The flesh-colored light seems to shine on his eyeball.

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S POV
dialogues.text: One of the BELLY DANCERS comes close, closer, closer...

dialogues.speaker: MR. CROSETTI
dialogues.text: He is sweating and staring as the belly dancers now come dancing nearer and nearer to him. His mouth is open and he starts to speak.

dialogues.speaker: CROSETTI
dialogues.text: Come close to me, ladies! Let me smell your perfume. Let me into the sweet-smelling skin of you. His voice cracks on a high note. His lips seem to have become fuller and redder, his hair longer, and Mr. Croset is beginning to take on the appearance of a lady. Then we see the belly dancers dancing even closer and more sensu- ously. They wind their diaphanous veils around him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim is still watching through the hole in the tent when: CRACK! A cane bangs the tent near Jim's cheek. He jumps.

dialogues.speaker: A GROTESQUE DWARF
dialogues.text: LAUGHING at him.

dialogues.speaker: DWARF
dialogues.text: Sorry, boys! Too young! Come back in ten years! A small group gathered around LAUGHS, ROARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two boys skulk off, Will ahead, head down, blushing, Jim following hang-dog. CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as:

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, I just saw -

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Shut up! I don't wanna hear!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Okay, you dimwit Episcopalean holy-roller!  Prod. 0233 - 8/24/81 35. 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys see their schoolteacher, Miss Foley, standing, Staring in at the mirrors. : JIM and WILL Hey, look - it's Miss Foley! Miss Foley moves into the Maze out of sight. The boys app and they too peer in at the mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Wanna go in?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No... For Will is looking deep. Jim looks with him.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAZE
dialogues.text: which is subterranean, which is deep and filled with ancient shadows and WHISPERS.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jim squints and asks:

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No? Will studies the maze, listens to it, and feels an Arctic wind blowing out from it. We can faintly HEAR that wind. His face is pale.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Those mirrors are like... last night.

dialogues.speaker: THE MIRRORS
dialogues.text: dissolve coldly, darkly, and the WIND blows softly.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: Both stand with their hair ruffled by the WIND, peering. MISS FOLEY'S VOICE 0.s. Oh yes... yes... yes. Please... The boys stare at each other - then back at: The maze where shadows run, half seen.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The boys dart to the entrance. MISS FOLEY'sS VOICE 0.s. Please...! oh yes... please...! Miss Foley blunders forth. They catch and retrieve her balance for her. She blinks around, stunned, and at last recognizes them. .

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Miss Foley! What's wrong, Miss Foley?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hey! Here we are, Miss Foley. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: MISS FOLEY
dialogues.text: Jim...! will! My two whisperers! I'm all right now. Of course I am. She peers back into the maze.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FOLEY
dialogues.text: Silly... I must be tired out, I guess. Why, it's so bright in there, and beautiful. So brilliant. It must have dazzled me! I can't quite remember... Miss Foley looks into the maze as if her memory had faile The two boys look at her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FOLEY
dialogues.text: (blinks, tries to pull herself to- gether) I must get home... my little nephew... She moves away, still in half a trance.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Is she ill?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hell, no. Must be a shock, though, Staring in all them mirrors. "Specially if you have a face like they use to scare the birds away.  Prod. 0233 - 8/24/81 65 66 37. dialogues.text: MINUTES." The wheel has just finished spinning, and Mr. Cooger holds up a ticket. In the crowd we SEE Mr. Tetley, Sweating and eager, as he pushes forward, waving his own ticket, almost speechless with joy.

dialogues.speaker: TETLEY
dialogues.text: It's my number! At last! It's my number! Look! Look at this!

dialogues.speaker: COOGER
dialogues.text: (taking ticket) Why, so it is, sir. No need to agitate yourself, so it is! He counts out money into Mr. Tetley's sweating palm.

dialogues.speaker: COOGER
dialogues.text: (continuing) And may I offer you a cigar, sir? (takes one out of his vest pocket) A Genuine Havana Special rolled for you on the plump thighs of Cuban beauties. And, of course, a free ride on our magnificent ferris wheel with the Management's compliments. Mr. Tetley kisses the money, pockets it, goes to the ferr wheel. Surprised but pleased, Mr. Tetley does so, lights his long Special cigar, puffs out smoke luxuriousl As Mr. Cooger pulls a lever and the ferris wheel starts t turn, Mr. Tetley looks around proudly, SEES something o.s waves towards:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys wave back, then turn to look at the caravan - th same one, dusty and deserted, which they saw the night before. They stare at a big padlock on the door. ae

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Locked up now.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It wasn't last night. It didn't seem such a plain ordinary carni- . val then, did it. Look! He points to a sign tacked up on a post near the caravan at the edge of the carnival. It reads: "WEEXDAYS ONLY - SUNRISE TO SUNDOWN ONLY." ae

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I bet something goes on after * sundown. We gotta stay and see!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We can't stay after it closes. They'll chuck us out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Not if they can't find us, they * won't! He gets down on his hands and knees, starts to crawl unde the caravan wheels. Will reluctantly follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER CARAVAN
dialogues.text: Will, crawling, encounters an ebstacle which JINGLES as he does so. He lets out an "OUCH" of pain, which halts Jim in his tracks. the boys sit up and peer at... a familiar, scuffed old leather bag. Will upends it and a jumble of lightning reds falls out between them. Will touches them wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The lightning rod salesman!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Mister Fury!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It's his bag! He wouldn't just leave it around... * They stare at each other a moment. Jim puts a hand on Will's arm. ae

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Will... we gotta wait...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No! He jerks loose and, in doing so, catches his hand on one of the lightning rods, cutting himself. He CRIES out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Mr. Halloway looks at Will, then sits on the edge of his bed. There's a long pause. Then he says:

dialogues.text: I guess I didn't like my father much, a lot of the time. Will looks at him, doesn't speak.

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY, (CONTD.)
dialogues.text: He thought a lot of book learn- ing. Swimming and dancing, he guessed they were evil - the work of the devil. That's why I never learned to swim in the river like the other boys. I wasn't ever allowed even to play with them. So I just read every darn book I could put my hand to...

dialogues.text: You don't have to tell me all that.

dialogues.text: No... But I'd like to, Will... I'd surely like to...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (thinking of something else) Granpa was a good man?

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWAY
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Everyone thought so.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And he knew about evil. Really knew...?

dialogues.text: He sure talked a lot about it. We had devils for breakfast, lunch and supper in our house.
